trans-unit.source: Create a .NET WebJob in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Create a .NET WebJob in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create a multi-tier app using ASP.NET MVC and Azure. The frontend runs in a web app in Azure App Service, and the backend runs as a WebJob. The app uses Entity Framework, SQL Database, and Azure storage queues and blobs.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create a multi-tier app using ASP.NET MVC and Azure. The frontend runs in a web app in Azure App Service, and the backend runs as a WebJob. The app uses Entity Framework, SQL Database, and Azure storage queues and blobs.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to create a multi-tier ASP.NET MVC application that uses the WebJobs SDK to work with <linkText>Azure queues</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Azure blobs</linkText><title></title> in a web app in <linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to create a multi-tier ASP.NET MVC application that uses the WebJobs SDK to work with <linkText>Azure queues</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Azure blobs</linkText><title></title> in a web app in <linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The application also uses <linkText>Azure SQL Database</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The application also uses <linkText>Azure SQL Database</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The sample application is an advertising bulletin board.
trans-unit.target: The sample application is an advertising bulletin board.

trans-unit.source: Users create an ad by entering text and uploading an image.
trans-unit.target: Users create an ad by entering text and uploading an image.

trans-unit.source: They can see a list of ads with thumbnail images, and they can see the full size image when they select an ad to see the details.
trans-unit.target: They can see a list of ads with thumbnail images, and they can see the full size image when they select an ad to see the details.

trans-unit.source: Here's a screenshot:
trans-unit.target: Here's a screenshot:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Ad list</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Ad list</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can <linkText>download the Visual Studio project[download]</linkText><title></title> from the MSDN Code Gallery.
trans-unit.target: You can <linkText>download the Visual Studio project[download]</linkText><title></title> from the MSDN Code Gallery.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial assumes that you know how to work with <linkText>ASP.NET MVC</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>Web Forms</linkText><title></title> projects in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial assumes that you know how to work with <linkText>ASP.NET MVC</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>Web Forms</linkText><title></title> projects in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: The sample application uses MVC, but most of the tutorial also applies to Web Forms.
trans-unit.target: The sample application uses MVC, but most of the tutorial also applies to Web Forms.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial instructions work with the following products:
trans-unit.target: The tutorial instructions work with the following products:

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 Community
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 Community

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 Express for Web
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 Express for Web

trans-unit.source: If you don't have one of these, Visual Studio 2013 Express for Web will be installed automatically when you install the Azure SDK.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have one of these, Visual Studio 2013 Express for Web will be installed automatically when you install the Azure SDK.

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial shows how to do the following tasks:
trans-unit.target: The tutorial shows how to do the following tasks:

trans-unit.source: Enable your machine for Azure development by installing the Azure SDK.
trans-unit.target: Enable your machine for Azure development by installing the Azure SDK.

trans-unit.source: Create a Console Application project that automatically deploys as an Azure WebJob when you deploy the associated web project.
trans-unit.target: Create a Console Application project that automatically deploys as an Azure WebJob when you deploy the associated web project.

trans-unit.source: Test a WebJobs SDK backend locally on the development computer.
trans-unit.target: Test a WebJobs SDK backend locally on the development computer.

trans-unit.source: Publish an application with a WebJobs backend to a web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: Publish an application with a WebJobs backend to a web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: Upload files and store them in the Azure Blob service.
trans-unit.target: Upload files and store them in the Azure Blob service.

trans-unit.source: Use the Azure WebJobs SDK to work with Azure Storage queues and blobs.
trans-unit.target: Use the Azure WebJobs SDK to work with Azure Storage queues and blobs.

trans-unit.source: The sample application uses the <linkText>queue-centric work pattern</linkText><title></title> to off-load the CPU-intensive work of creating thumbnails to a backend process.
trans-unit.target: The sample application uses the <linkText>queue-centric work pattern</linkText><title></title> to off-load the CPU-intensive work of creating thumbnails to a backend process.

trans-unit.source: The app stores ads in a SQL database, using Entity Framework Code First to create the tables and access the data.
trans-unit.target: The app stores ads in a SQL database, using Entity Framework Code First to create the tables and access the data.

trans-unit.source: For each ad, the database stores two URLs: one for the full-size image and one for the thumbnail.
trans-unit.target: For each ad, the database stores two URLs: one for the full-size image and one for the thumbnail.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Ad table</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Ad table</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When a user uploads an image, the frontend of the web app stores the image in an <linkText>Azure blob</linkText><title></title>, and it stores the ad information in the database with a URL that points to the blob.
trans-unit.target: When a user uploads an image, the frontend of the web app stores the image in an <linkText>Azure blob</linkText><title></title>, and it stores the ad information in the database with a URL that points to the blob.

trans-unit.source: At the same time, it writes a message to an Azure queue.
trans-unit.target: At the same time, it writes a message to an Azure queue.

trans-unit.source: A backend process running as an Azure WebJob uses the WebJobs SDK to poll the queue for new messages.
trans-unit.target: A backend process running as an Azure WebJob uses the WebJobs SDK to poll the queue for new messages.

trans-unit.source: When a new message appears, the WebJob creates a thumbnail for that image and updates the thumbnail URL database field for that ad.
trans-unit.target: When a new message appears, the WebJob creates a thumbnail for that image and updates the thumbnail URL database field for that ad.

trans-unit.source: Here's a diagram that shows how the parts of the application interact:
trans-unit.target: Here's a diagram that shows how the parts of the application interact:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Contoso Ads architecture</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Contoso Ads architecture</linkText>

trans-unit.source: WebJobs run in the context of a web app and are not scalable separately.
trans-unit.target: WebJobs run in the context of a web app and are not scalable separately.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you have one Standard web app instance, you have only one instance of your background process running, and it is using some of the server resources (CPU, memory, etc.)
trans-unit.target: For example, if you have one Standard web app instance, you have only one instance of your background process running, and it is using some of the server resources (CPU, memory, etc.)

trans-unit.source: that otherwise would be available to serve web content.
trans-unit.target: that otherwise would be available to serve web content.

trans-unit.source: If traffic varies by time of day or day of week, and if the backend processing you need to do can wait, you could schedule your WebJobs to run at low-traffic times.
trans-unit.target: If traffic varies by time of day or day of week, and if the backend processing you need to do can wait, you could schedule your WebJobs to run at low-traffic times.

trans-unit.source: If the load is still too high for that solution, you can consider alternative environments for your backend program, such as the following:
trans-unit.target: If the load is still too high for that solution, you can consider alternative environments for your backend program, such as the following:

trans-unit.source: Run the program as a WebJob in a separate web app dedicated for that purpose.
trans-unit.target: Run the program as a WebJob in a separate web app dedicated for that purpose.

trans-unit.source: You can then scale your backend web app independently from your frontend web app.
trans-unit.target: You can then scale your backend web app independently from your frontend web app.

trans-unit.source: Run the program in an Azure Cloud Service worker role.
trans-unit.target: Run the program in an Azure Cloud Service worker role.

trans-unit.source: If you choose this option, you could run the frontend in either a Cloud Service web role or a web app.
trans-unit.target: If you choose this option, you could run the frontend in either a Cloud Service web role or a web app.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to run the frontend in a web app and the backend as a WebJob in the same web app.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to run the frontend in a web app and the backend as a WebJob in the same web app.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to choose the best environment for your scenario, see <linkText>Azure web app, cloud services, and virtual machines comparison</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to choose the best environment for your scenario, see <linkText>Azure web app, cloud services, and virtual machines comparison</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial instructions apply to Azure SDK for .NET 2.5.1 or later.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial instructions apply to Azure SDK for .NET 2.5.1 or later.

trans-unit.source: In the create-from-scratch section where you create the WebJob project, the WebJobs SDK packages are automatically included in the project; with earlier versions of the SDK you have to install the packages manually.
trans-unit.target: In the create-from-scratch section where you create the WebJob project, the WebJobs SDK packages are automatically included in the project; with earlier versions of the SDK you have to install the packages manually.

trans-unit.source: An Azure storage account provides resources for storing queue and blob data in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: An Azure storage account provides resources for storing queue and blob data in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: It is also used by the WebJobs SDK to store logging data for the dashboard.
trans-unit.target: It is also used by the WebJobs SDK to store logging data for the dashboard.

trans-unit.source: In a real-world application, you typically create separate accounts for application data versus logging data, and separate accounts for test data versus production data.
trans-unit.target: In a real-world application, you typically create separate accounts for application data versus logging data, and separate accounts for test data versus production data.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial you'll use just one account.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial you'll use just one account.

trans-unit.source: Open the Server Explorer window in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Open the Server Explorer window in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the Azure node, and then click Connect to Microsoft Azure.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the Azure node, and then click Connect to Microsoft Azure.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Connect to Azure</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Connect to Azure</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Sign in using your Azure credentials.
trans-unit.target: Sign in using your Azure credentials.

trans-unit.source: Right-click Storage under the Azure node, and then click Create Storage Account.
trans-unit.target: Right-click Storage under the Azure node, and then click Create Storage Account.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create Storage Account</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create Storage Account</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Create Storage Account dialog, enter a name for the storage account.
trans-unit.target: In the Create Storage Account dialog, enter a name for the storage account.

trans-unit.source: The name must be must be unique (no other Azure storage account can have the same name).
trans-unit.target: The name must be must be unique (no other Azure storage account can have the same name).

trans-unit.source: If the name you enter is already in use you'll get a chance to change it.
trans-unit.target: If the name you enter is already in use you'll get a chance to change it.

trans-unit.source: The URL to access your storage account will be {name}.core.windows.net.
trans-unit.target: The URL to access your storage account will be {name}.core.windows.net.

trans-unit.source: Set the Region or Affinity Group drop-down list to the region closest to you.
trans-unit.target: Set the Region or Affinity Group drop-down list to the region closest to you.

trans-unit.source: This setting specifies which Azure datacenter will host your storage account.
trans-unit.target: This setting specifies which Azure datacenter will host your storage account.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial, your choice won't make a noticeable difference.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, your choice won't make a noticeable difference.

trans-unit.source: However, for a production web app, you want your web server and your storage account to be in the same region to minimize latency and data egress charges.
trans-unit.target: However, for a production web app, you want your web server and your storage account to be in the same region to minimize latency and data egress charges.

trans-unit.source: The web app (which you'll create later) datacenter should be as close as possible to the browsers accessing the web app in order to minimize latency.
trans-unit.target: The web app (which you'll create later) datacenter should be as close as possible to the browsers accessing the web app in order to minimize latency.

trans-unit.source: Set the Replication drop-down list to Locally redundant.
trans-unit.target: Set the Replication drop-down list to Locally redundant.

trans-unit.source: When geo-replication is enabled for a storage account, the stored content is replicated to a secondary datacenter to enable failover to that location in case of a major disaster in the primary location.
trans-unit.target: When geo-replication is enabled for a storage account, the stored content is replicated to a secondary datacenter to enable failover to that location in case of a major disaster in the primary location.

trans-unit.source: Geo-replication can incur additional costs.
trans-unit.target: Geo-replication can incur additional costs.

trans-unit.source: For test and development accounts, you generally don't want to pay for geo-replication.
trans-unit.target: For test and development accounts, you generally don't want to pay for geo-replication.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Create, manage, or delete a storage account</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Create, manage, or delete a storage account</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New storage account</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New storage account</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Download and unzip the <linkText>completed solution[download]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Download and unzip the <linkText>completed solution[download]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Start Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Start Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: From the File menu choose Open > Project/Solution, navigate to where you downloaded the solution, and then open the solution file.
trans-unit.target: From the File menu choose Open > Project/Solution, navigate to where you downloaded the solution, and then open the solution file.

trans-unit.source: Press CTRL+SHIFT+B to build the solution.
trans-unit.target: Press CTRL+SHIFT+B to build the solution.

trans-unit.source: By default, Visual Studio automatically restores the NuGet package content, which was not included in the .zip file.
trans-unit.target: By default, Visual Studio automatically restores the NuGet package content, which was not included in the .zip file.

trans-unit.source: If the packages don't restore, install them manually by going to the Manage NuGet Packages for Solution dialog and clicking the Restore button at the top right.
trans-unit.target: If the packages don't restore, install them manually by going to the Manage NuGet Packages for Solution dialog and clicking the Restore button at the top right.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, make sure that ContosoAdsWeb is selected as the startup project.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, make sure that ContosoAdsWeb is selected as the startup project.

trans-unit.source: Open the application Web.config file in the ContosoAdsWeb project.
trans-unit.target: Open the application Web.config file in the ContosoAdsWeb project.

trans-unit.source: The file contains a SQL connection string and an Azure storage connection string for working with blobs and queues.
trans-unit.target: The file contains a SQL connection string and an Azure storage connection string for working with blobs and queues.

trans-unit.source: The SQL connection string points to a <linkText>SQL Server Express LocalDB</linkText><title></title> database.
trans-unit.target: The SQL connection string points to a <linkText>SQL Server Express LocalDB</linkText><title></title> database.

trans-unit.source: The storage connection string is an example that has placeholders for the storage account name and access key.
trans-unit.target: The storage connection string is an example that has placeholders for the storage account name and access key.

trans-unit.source: You'll replace this with a connection string that has the name and key of your storage account.
trans-unit.target: You'll replace this with a connection string that has the name and key of your storage account.

trans-unit.source: [accountname]
trans-unit.target: [accountname]

trans-unit.source: ;AccountKey=
trans-unit.target: ;AccountKey=

trans-unit.source: [accesskey]
trans-unit.target: [accesskey]

trans-unit.source: "/> </connectionStrings>
trans-unit.target: "/> </connectionStrings>

trans-unit.source: The storage connection string is named AzureWebJobsStorage because that's the name the WebJobs SDK uses by default.
trans-unit.target: The storage connection string is named AzureWebJobsStorage because that's the name the WebJobs SDK uses by default.

trans-unit.source: The same name is used here so you have to set only one connection string value in the Azure environment.
trans-unit.target: The same name is used here so you have to set only one connection string value in the Azure environment.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, right-click your storage account under the Storage node, and then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, right-click your storage account under the Storage node, and then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click Storage Account Properties</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click Storage Account Properties</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Properties window, click Storage Account Keys, and then click the ellipsis.
trans-unit.target: In the Properties window, click Storage Account Keys, and then click the ellipsis.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New storage account</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New storage account</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Copy the Connection String.
trans-unit.target: Copy the Connection String.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Storage Account Keys dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Storage Account Keys dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Replace the storage connection string in the Web.config file with the connection string you just copied.
trans-unit.target: Replace the storage connection string in the Web.config file with the connection string you just copied.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you select everything inside the quotation marks but not including the quotation marks before pasting.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you select everything inside the quotation marks but not including the quotation marks before pasting.

trans-unit.source: Open the App.config file in the ContosoAdsWebJob project.
trans-unit.target: Open the App.config file in the ContosoAdsWebJob project.

trans-unit.source: This file has two storage connection strings, one for application data and one for logging.
trans-unit.target: This file has two storage connection strings, one for application data and one for logging.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial you'll use the same account for both.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial you'll use the same account for both.

trans-unit.source: The connection strings have placeholders for the storage account keys.
trans-unit.target: The connection strings have placeholders for the storage account keys.

trans-unit.source: [accountname]
trans-unit.target: [accountname]

trans-unit.source: ;AccountKey=
trans-unit.target: ;AccountKey=

trans-unit.source: [accesskey]
trans-unit.target: [accesskey]

trans-unit.source: "/> <add name="AzureWebJobsStorage" connectionString="DefaultEndpointsProtocol=https;AccountName=
trans-unit.target: "/> <add name="AzureWebJobsStorage" connectionString="DefaultEndpointsProtocol=https;AccountName=

trans-unit.source: [accountname]
trans-unit.target: [accountname]

trans-unit.source: ;AccountKey=
trans-unit.target: ;AccountKey=

trans-unit.source: [accesskey]
trans-unit.target: [accesskey]

trans-unit.source: By default, the WebJobs SDK looks for connection strings named AzureWebJobsStorage and AzureWebJobsDashboard.
trans-unit.target: By default, the WebJobs SDK looks for connection strings named AzureWebJobsStorage and AzureWebJobsDashboard.

trans-unit.source: As an alternative, you can [store the connection string however you want and pass it in explicitly to the JobHost object](websites-dotnet-webjobs-sdk-storage-queues-how-to.md#config).
trans-unit.target: As an alternative, you can [store the connection string however you want and pass it in explicitly to the JobHost object](websites-dotnet-webjobs-sdk-storage-queues-how-to.md#config).

trans-unit.source: Replace both storage connection strings with the connection string you copied earlier.
trans-unit.target: Replace both storage connection strings with the connection string you copied earlier.

trans-unit.source: Save your changes.
trans-unit.target: Save your changes.

trans-unit.source: To start the web frontend of the application, press CTRL+F5.
trans-unit.target: To start the web frontend of the application, press CTRL+F5.

trans-unit.source: The default browser opens to the home page.
trans-unit.target: The default browser opens to the home page.

trans-unit.source: (The web project runs because you've made it the startup project.)
trans-unit.target: (The web project runs because you've made it the startup project.)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Contoso Ads home page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Contoso Ads home page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To start the WebJob backend of the application, right-click the ContosoAdsWebJob project in Solution Explorer, and then click Debug > Start new instance.
trans-unit.target: To start the WebJob backend of the application, right-click the ContosoAdsWebJob project in Solution Explorer, and then click Debug > Start new instance.

trans-unit.source: A console application window opens and displays logging messages indicating the WebJobs SDK JobHost object has started to run.
trans-unit.target: A console application window opens and displays logging messages indicating the WebJobs SDK JobHost object has started to run.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Console application window showing that the backend is running</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Console application window showing that the backend is running</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In your browser, click Create an Ad.
trans-unit.target: In your browser, click Create an Ad.

trans-unit.source: Enter some test data and select an image to upload, and then click Create.
trans-unit.target: Enter some test data and select an image to upload, and then click Create.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The app goes to the Index page, but it doesn't show a thumbnail for the new ad because that processing hasn't happened yet.
trans-unit.target: The app goes to the Index page, but it doesn't show a thumbnail for the new ad because that processing hasn't happened yet.

trans-unit.source: Meanwhile, after a short wait a logging message in the console application window shows that a queue message was received and has been processed.
trans-unit.target: Meanwhile, after a short wait a logging message in the console application window shows that a queue message was received and has been processed.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Console application window showing that a queue message has been processed</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Console application window showing that a queue message has been processed</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After you see the logging messages in the console application window, refresh the Index page to see the thumbnail.
trans-unit.target: After you see the logging messages in the console application window, refresh the Index page to see the thumbnail.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Index page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Index page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Details for your ad to see the full-size image.
trans-unit.target: Click Details for your ad to see the full-size image.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Details page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Details page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You've been running the application on your local computer, and it's using a SQL Server database located on your computer, but it's working with queues and blobs in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: You've been running the application on your local computer, and it's using a SQL Server database located on your computer, but it's working with queues and blobs in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: In the following section you'll run the application in the cloud, using a cloud database as well as cloud blobs and queues.
trans-unit.target: In the following section you'll run the application in the cloud, using a cloud database as well as cloud blobs and queues.

trans-unit.source: You'll do the following steps to run the application in the cloud:
trans-unit.target: You'll do the following steps to run the application in the cloud:

trans-unit.source: Deploy to Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: Deploy to Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio will automatically create a new web app in App Service and SQL Database instance.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio will automatically create a new web app in App Service and SQL Database instance.

trans-unit.source: Configure the web app to use your Azure SQL database and storage account.
trans-unit.target: Configure the web app to use your Azure SQL database and storage account.

trans-unit.source: After you've created some ads while running in the cloud, you'll view the WebJobs SDK dashboard to see the rich monitoring features it has to offer.
trans-unit.target: After you've created some ads while running in the cloud, you'll view the WebJobs SDK dashboard to see the rich monitoring features it has to offer.

trans-unit.source: Close the browser and the console application window.
trans-unit.target: Close the browser and the console application window.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the ContosoAdsWeb project, and then click Publish.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the ContosoAdsWeb project, and then click Publish.

trans-unit.source: In the Profile step of the Publish Web wizard, click Microsoft Azure web apps.
trans-unit.target: In the Profile step of the Publish Web wizard, click Microsoft Azure web apps.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Select Azure web app publish target</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Select Azure web app publish target</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Select existing web app box, click Sign In and enter your credentials if you're not already signed in.
trans-unit.target: In the Select existing web app box, click Sign In and enter your credentials if you're not already signed in.

trans-unit.source: After you're signed in, click New.
trans-unit.target: After you're signed in, click New.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click New</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click New</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Create web app on Microsoft Azure dialog box, enter a unique name in the Web app name box.
trans-unit.target: In the Create web app on Microsoft Azure dialog box, enter a unique name in the Web app name box.

trans-unit.source: The complete URL will consist of what you enter here plus .azurewebsites.net (as shown next to the Web app name text box).
trans-unit.target: The complete URL will consist of what you enter here plus .azurewebsites.net (as shown next to the Web app name text box).

trans-unit.source: For example, if the web app name is ContosoAds, the URL will be ContosoAds.azurewebsites.net.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the web app name is ContosoAds, the URL will be ContosoAds.azurewebsites.net.

trans-unit.source: In the App Service plan drop-down list choose Create new App Service plan.
trans-unit.target: In the App Service plan drop-down list choose Create new App Service plan.

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for the App Service plan, such as ContosoAdsPlan.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for the App Service plan, such as ContosoAdsPlan.

trans-unit.source: In the Resource group drop-down list choose Create new resource group.
trans-unit.target: In the Resource group drop-down list choose Create new resource group.

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for the resource group, such as ContosoAdsGroup.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for the resource group, such as ContosoAdsGroup.

trans-unit.source: It's a security best practice to <linkText>avoid putting sensitive information such as connection strings in files that are stored in source code repositories</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Azure provides a way to do that: you can set connection string and other setting values in the Azure environment, and ASP.NET configuration APIs automatically pick up these values when the app runs in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Azure provides a way to do that: you can set connection string and other setting values in the Azure environment, and ASP.NET configuration APIs automatically pick up these values when the app runs in Azure.

trans-unit.source: You can set these values in Azure by using Server Explorer, the portal, Windows PowerShell, or the cross-platform command-line interface.

trans-unit.source: The following sections explain the code related to working with the WebJobs SDK and Azure Storage blobs and queues.
trans-unit.target: The following sections explain the code related to working with the WebJobs SDK and Azure Storage blobs and queues.

trans-unit.source: Note: For the code specific to the WebJobs SDK, see Program.cs and Functions.cs.
trans-unit.target: Note: For the code specific to the WebJobs SDK, see Program.cs and Functions.cs.

trans-unit.source: The Ad.cs file defines an enum for ad categories and a POCO entity class for ad information.
trans-unit.target: The Ad.cs file defines an enum for ad categories and a POCO entity class for ad information.

trans-unit.source: The ContosoAdsContext class specifies that the Ad class is used in a DbSet collection, which Entity Framework will store in a SQL database.
trans-unit.target: The ContosoAdsContext class specifies that the Ad class is used in a DbSet collection, which Entity Framework will store in a SQL database.

trans-unit.source: The class has two constructors.
trans-unit.target: The class has two constructors.

trans-unit.source: The first of them is used by the web project, and specifies the name of a connection string that is stored in the Web.config file or the Azure runtime environment.
trans-unit.target: The first of them is used by the web project, and specifies the name of a connection string that is stored in the Web.config file or the Azure runtime environment.

trans-unit.source: The second constructor enables you to pass in the actual connection string.
trans-unit.target: The second constructor enables you to pass in the actual connection string.

trans-unit.source: That is needed by the WebJob project, since it doesn't have a Web.config file.
trans-unit.target: That is needed by the WebJob project, since it doesn't have a Web.config file.

trans-unit.source: You saw earlier where this connection string was stored, and you'll see later how the code retrieves the connection string when it instantiates the DbContext class.
trans-unit.target: You saw earlier where this connection string was stored, and you'll see later how the code retrieves the connection string when it instantiates the DbContext class.

trans-unit.source: The BlobInformation class is used to store information about an image blob in a queue message.
trans-unit.target: The BlobInformation class is used to store information about an image blob in a queue message.

trans-unit.source: Code that is called from the Application_Start method creates an images blob container and an images queue if they don't already exist.
trans-unit.target: Code that is called from the Application_Start method creates an images blob container and an images queue if they don't already exist.

trans-unit.source: This ensures that whenever you start using a new storage account, the required blob container and queue will be created automatically.
trans-unit.target: This ensures that whenever you start using a new storage account, the required blob container and queue will be created automatically.

trans-unit.source: The code gets access to the storage account by using the storage connection string from the Web.config file or Azure runtime environment.
trans-unit.target: The code gets access to the storage account by using the storage connection string from the Web.config file or Azure runtime environment.

trans-unit.source: Then it gets a reference to the images blob container, creates the container if it doesn't already exist, and sets access permissions on the new container.
trans-unit.target: Then it gets a reference to the images blob container, creates the container if it doesn't already exist, and sets access permissions on the new container.

trans-unit.source: By default new containers allow only clients with storage account credentials to access blobs.
trans-unit.target: By default new containers allow only clients with storage account credentials to access blobs.

trans-unit.source: The web app needs the blobs to be public so that it can display images using URLs that point to the image blobs.
trans-unit.target: The web app needs the blobs to be public so that it can display images using URLs that point to the image blobs.

trans-unit.source: Similar code gets a reference to the blobnamerequest queue and creates a new queue.
trans-unit.target: Similar code gets a reference to the blobnamerequest queue and creates a new queue.

trans-unit.source: In this case no permissions change is needed.
trans-unit.target: In this case no permissions change is needed.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>ResolveBlobName</linkText><title></title> section later in the tutorial explains why the queue that the web application writes to is used just for getting blob names and not for generating thumbnails.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>ResolveBlobName</linkText><title></title> section later in the tutorial explains why the queue that the web application writes to is used just for getting blob names and not for generating thumbnails.

trans-unit.target: The _Layout.cshtml file sets the app name in the header and footer, and creates an "Ads" menu entry.

trans-unit.target: The Views\Home\Index.cshtml file displays category links on the home page.

trans-unit.source: The links pass the integer value of the Category enum in a querystring variable to the Ads Index page.
trans-unit.target: The links pass the integer value of the Category enum in a querystring variable to the Ads Index page.

trans-unit.source: In the AdController.cs file the constructor calls the InitializeStorage method to create Azure Storage Client Library objects that provide an API for working with blobs and queues.
trans-unit.target: In the AdController.cs file the constructor calls the InitializeStorage method to create Azure Storage Client Library objects that provide an API for working with blobs and queues.

trans-unit.source: Then the code gets a reference to the images blob container as you saw earlier in Global.asax.cs.
trans-unit.target: Then the code gets a reference to the images blob container as you saw earlier in Global.asax.cs.

trans-unit.source: While doing that it sets a default <linkText>retry policy</linkText><title></title> appropriate for a web app.
trans-unit.target: While doing that it sets a default <linkText>retry policy</linkText><title></title> appropriate for a web app.

trans-unit.source: The default exponential backoff retry policy could hang the web app for longer than a minute on repeated retries for a transient fault.
trans-unit.target: The default exponential backoff retry policy could hang the web app for longer than a minute on repeated retries for a transient fault.

trans-unit.source: The retry policy specified here waits 3 seconds after each try for up to 3 tries.
trans-unit.target: The retry policy specified here waits 3 seconds after each try for up to 3 tries.

trans-unit.source: Similar code gets a reference to the images queue.
trans-unit.target: Similar code gets a reference to the images queue.

trans-unit.target: Most of the controller code is typical for working with an Entity Framework data model using a DbContext class.

trans-unit.source: An exception is the HttpPost Create method, which uploads a file and saves it in blob storage.
trans-unit.target: An exception is the HttpPost Create method, which uploads a file and saves it in blob storage.

trans-unit.source: The model binder provides an <linkText>HttpPostedFileBase</linkText><title></title> object to the method.
trans-unit.target: The model binder provides an <linkText>HttpPostedFileBase</linkText><title></title> object to the method.

trans-unit.source: If the user selected a file to upload, the code uploads the file, saves it in a blob, and updates the Ad database record with a URL that points to the blob.
trans-unit.target: If the user selected a file to upload, the code uploads the file, saves it in a blob, and updates the Ad database record with a URL that points to the blob.

trans-unit.source: The code that does the upload is in the UploadAndSaveBlobAsync method.
trans-unit.target: The code that does the upload is in the UploadAndSaveBlobAsync method.

trans-unit.source: It creates a GUID name for the blob, uploads and saves the file, and returns a reference to the saved blob.
trans-unit.target: It creates a GUID name for the blob, uploads and saves the file, and returns a reference to the saved blob.

trans-unit.source: After the HttpPost Create method uploads a blob and updates the database, it creates a queue message to inform the back-end process that an image is ready for conversion to a thumbnail.
trans-unit.target: After the HttpPost Create method uploads a blob and updates the database, it creates a queue message to inform the back-end process that an image is ready for conversion to a thumbnail.

trans-unit.source: When the WebJob starts, the Main method calls the WebJobs SDK JobHost.RunAndBlock method to begin execution of triggered functions on the current thread.
trans-unit.target: When the WebJob starts, the Main method calls the WebJobs SDK JobHost.RunAndBlock method to begin execution of triggered functions on the current thread.

trans-unit.source: The WebJobs SDK calls this method when a queue message is received.
trans-unit.target: The WebJobs SDK calls this method when a queue message is received.

trans-unit.source: The method creates a thumbnail and puts the thumbnail URL in the database.
trans-unit.target: The method creates a thumbnail and puts the thumbnail URL in the database.

trans-unit.source: The QueueTrigger attribute directs the WebJobs SDK to call this method when a new message is received on the thumbnailrequest queue.
trans-unit.target: The QueueTrigger attribute directs the WebJobs SDK to call this method when a new message is received on the thumbnailrequest queue.

trans-unit.source: The BlobInformation object in the queue message is automatically deserialized into the blobInfo parameter.
trans-unit.target: The BlobInformation object in the queue message is automatically deserialized into the blobInfo parameter.

trans-unit.source: When the method completes, the queue message is deleted.
trans-unit.target: When the method completes, the queue message is deleted.

trans-unit.source: If the method fails before completing, the queue message is not deleted; after a 10-minute lease expires, the message is released to be picked up again and processed.
trans-unit.target: If the method fails before completing, the queue message is not deleted; after a 10-minute lease expires, the message is released to be picked up again and processed.

trans-unit.source: This sequence won't be repeated indefinitely if a message always causes an exception.
trans-unit.target: This sequence won't be repeated indefinitely if a message always causes an exception.

trans-unit.source: After 5 unsuccessful attempts to process a message, the message is moved to a queue named {queuename}-poison.
trans-unit.target: After 5 unsuccessful attempts to process a message, the message is moved to a queue named {queuename}-poison.

trans-unit.source: The maximum number of attempts is configurable.
trans-unit.target: The maximum number of attempts is configurable.

trans-unit.source: The two Blob attributes provide objects that are bound to blobs: one to the existing image blob and one to a new thumbnail blob that the method creates.
trans-unit.target: The two Blob attributes provide objects that are bound to blobs: one to the existing image blob and one to a new thumbnail blob that the method creates.

trans-unit.source: Blob names come from properties of the BlobInformation object received in the queue message (BlobName and BlobNameWithoutExtension).
trans-unit.target: Blob names come from properties of the BlobInformation object received in the queue message (BlobName and BlobNameWithoutExtension).

trans-unit.target: This is not a problem if you use the built-in queue, blob, and Service Bus triggers.

trans-unit.source: If you compare the amount of code in the GenerateThumbnails method in this sample application with the worker role code in the Cloud Service version of the application, you can see how much work the WebJobs SDK is doing for you.
trans-unit.target: If you compare the amount of code in the GenerateThumbnails method in this sample application with the worker role code in the Cloud Service version of the application, you can see how much work the WebJobs SDK is doing for you.

trans-unit.source: The advantage is greater than it appears, because the Cloud Service sample application code doesn't do all of the things (such as poison message handling) that you would do in a production application, and which the WebJobs SDK does for you.
trans-unit.target: The advantage is greater than it appears, because the Cloud Service sample application code doesn't do all of the things (such as poison message handling) that you would do in a production application, and which the WebJobs SDK does for you.

trans-unit.source: In the Cloud Service version of the application, the record ID is the only information in the queue message, and the background process gets the image URL from the database.
trans-unit.target: In the Cloud Service version of the application, the record ID is the only information in the queue message, and the background process gets the image URL from the database.

trans-unit.source: In the WebJobs SDK version of the application, the queue message includes the image URL so that it can be provided to the Blob attributes.
trans-unit.target: In the WebJobs SDK version of the application, the queue message includes the image URL so that it can be provided to the Blob attributes.

trans-unit.source: If the queue message didn't have the blob URL, you could <linkText>use the Blob attribute in the body of the method instead of in the method signature</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If the queue message didn't have the blob URL, you could <linkText>use the Blob attribute in the body of the method instead of in the method signature</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: A program that uses the WebJobs SDK doesn't have to run in Azure in a WebJob.
trans-unit.target: A program that uses the WebJobs SDK doesn't have to run in Azure in a WebJob.

trans-unit.source: It can run locally, and it can also run in other environments such as a Cloud Service worker role or a Windows service.
trans-unit.target: It can run locally, and it can also run in other environments such as a Cloud Service worker role or a Windows service.

trans-unit.source: However, you can only access the WebJobs SDK dashboard through an Azure web app.
trans-unit.target: However, you can only access the WebJobs SDK dashboard through an Azure web app.

trans-unit.source: To use the dashboard you have to connect the web app to the storage account you're using by setting the AzureWebJobsDashboard connection string on the Configure tab of the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: To use the dashboard you have to connect the web app to the storage account you're using by setting the AzureWebJobsDashboard connection string on the Configure tab of the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: Then you can get to the Dashboard by using the following URL:
trans-unit.target: Then you can get to the Dashboard by using the following URL:

trans-unit.source: https://{webappname}.scm.azurewebsites.net/azurejobs/#/functions
trans-unit.target: https://{webappname}.scm.azurewebsites.net/azurejobs/#/functions

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Getting a dashboard for local development with the WebJobs SDK</linkText><title></title>, but note that it shows an old connection string name.
